subdomains.name: Elementary Algebra
subdomains.description: The foundation — variables, expressions, equations, and the language of mathematics.
subdomains.flavor: The First Star — every explorer's starting point. Simple, but everything grows from here.

topics.name: Variables & Expressions
topics.description: Using letters to represent unknown quantities. Building and simplifying algebraic expressions.
topics.flavor: The seed of all algebra — a single letter that can be anything.

topics.name: Linear Equations
topics.description: Equations of the form ax + b = c. Solving for unknowns using inverse operations.
topics.flavor: The straight paths of the universe — simple, elegant, and everywhere.

topics.name: Inequalities
topics.description: Relations using <, >, ≤, ≥. Solving and graphing inequalities on a number line.
topics.flavor: Not everything is equal — sometimes we only know the bounds.

topics.name: Systems of Equations
topics.description: Two or more equations with multiple unknowns. Substitution and elimination methods.
topics.flavor: Where two straight lines cross, a secret is revealed.

subdomains.name: Polynomials
subdomains.description: Expressions with multiple terms and powers. Factoring, roots, and the fundamental theorem of algebra.
subdomains.flavor: The Garden of Powers — where expressions bloom into complex and beautiful forms.

topics.name: Polynomial Operations
topics.description: Adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing polynomials. Long division and synthetic division.
topics.flavor: Combining powers — the arithmetic of expressions.

topics.name: Factoring
topics.description: Breaking polynomials into irreducible factors. GCF, grouping, difference of squares, sum/difference of cubes.
topics.flavor: Every polynomial hides a secret structure — factoring reveals it.

topics.name: Quadratic Equations
topics.description: ax² + bx + c = 0. The quadratic formula, completing the square, discriminant, and parabolas.
topics.flavor: The first curve — a parabola arcing through space, connecting algebra to geometry.

topics.name: Higher-Degree Polynomials
topics.description: Cubic, quartic, and beyond. Rational root theorem, Descartes' rule, and end behavior.
topics.flavor: The deeper you go, the wilder the curves become.

subdomains.name: Linear Algebra
subdomains.description: Vectors, matrices, linear transformations, eigenvalues. The backbone of modern applied mathematics.
subdomains.flavor: The Crystal Lattice — where dimensions multiply and spaces transform.

topics.name: Vectors
topics.description: Quantities with magnitude and direction. Vector addition, scalar multiplication, dot and cross products.
topics.flavor: Arrows in space — pointing the way to higher dimensions.

topics.name: Matrices
topics.description: Rectangular arrays of numbers. Matrix operations, determinants, and inverses.
topics.flavor: Grids of numbers that encode transformations of entire spaces.

topics.name: Linear Transformations
topics.description: Functions that preserve vector addition and scalar multiplication. Rotation, reflection, scaling.
topics.flavor: The universe warps and stretches — but linearly, always linearly.

topics.name: Eigenvalues & Eigenvectors
topics.description: Special vectors that only scale under a transformation. The key to understanding matrix behavior.
topics.flavor: The DNA of a transformation — the directions that refuse to change.

subdomains.name: Abstract Algebra
subdomains.description: Groups, rings, fields — the study of algebraic structures at their most general and abstract level.
subdomains.flavor: The Deep Core — where algebra becomes pure structure, stripped of all specifics.

topics.name: Group Theory
topics.description: Sets with a binary operation satisfying closure, associativity, identity, and inverses. Symmetry formalized.
topics.flavor: Symmetry itself, captured in pure mathematics.

topics.name: Ring Theory
topics.description: Sets with two operations (addition and multiplication). Ideals, quotient rings, and polynomial rings.

topics.name: Field Theory
topics.description: Rings where every nonzero element has a multiplicative inverse. Field extensions and Galois theory.
topics.flavor: The final frontier of classical algebra — where Galois proved some equations can never be solved.
